H0.text: Folding is the process that best explains how the Grand Canyon became so wide.

H1.text: Erosion is the process that best explains how the Grand Canyon became so wide.

H2.text: Deposition is the process that best explains how the Grand Canyon became so wide.

H3.text: Sedimentation is the process that best explains how the Grand Canyon became so wide.

A4.text: The great depth of the Grand Canyon and especially the height of its strata can be attributed to 5,000â€“10,000 feet of uplift of the Colorado Plateau, starting about 65 million years ago (during the Laramide orogeny). This uplift has steepened the stream gradient of the Colorado River and its tributaries, which in turn has increased their speed and thus their ability to cut through rock.

A5.text: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States.
